title: Joost van der Westhuizen and Jonah Lomu - friendship borne from rugby's ultimate rivalry
text:
Joost van der Westhuizen and Jonah Lomu - friendship borne from rugby's ultimate rivalry Last updated 13:42, February 7 2017 GETTY IMAGES 
Joost van der Westhuizen speaks to the All Blacks in 2014. 
Joost van der Westhuizen broke Kiwi hearts but also earned their respect as he set up a long and touching rivalry and friendship with Jonah Lomu. 
It was a mark of the regard All Blacks fans held for the Springboks great that they openly acknowledged his place as one of the games true greats. 
The rugged halfback, who died on Tuesday (NZ time) after his long battle with motor neurone disease, was a key figure in the Springboks denying the All Blacks a second World Cup victory in 1995. Stuff.co.nz 
Joost van der Westhuizen sends Lomu crashing to the ground. 
Lomu, the Kiwi man mountain, had dominated the tournament right up to the dramatic final with his try-scoring deeds. 
READ MORE: * Former Springboks captain has motor-neuron disease 
And he was threatening to spoil the party for the hosts, the newly democratic and post-apartheid South Africa. In the final at Johannesburg's Ellis Park, several times Lomu broke away and thundered towards the tryline, Springboks bouncing off him. Until Van der Westhuizen stood in his path. Three times the South Africa scrum half pulled off monumental tackles to send Lomu crashing to the ground. REUTERS 
Joost van der westhuizen cuts down a rampaging Jonah Lomu during the dramatic 1995 World Cup final in South Africa. 
One of them in particular will be remembered as long as rugby is played. 
"I was the lucky one," Van der Westhuizen joked about it years later. "I think he fell over me." 
That was the modest side of Van der Westhuizen, the ultimate competitor, as he reflected on a 15-12 result secured in extra time. 
But helping keep Lomu try-less in the final – a trait that continued through the big wing's career against the Boks – helped the Boks win their first World Cup and emphasise their glaring absence from the first two tournaments on political grounds. 
Touchingly, Van der Westhuizen won over Lomu as their careers blossomed on the back of that tournament. 
Their friendship lasted right up till Lomu's untimely death in late 2015. 
Like Van der Westhuizen, Lomu battled a life-threatening illness. 
No one expected the Springbok to outlast the All Black but that's the way it played out. 
Lomu's death hit Van der Westhuizen hard. "Difficult to write with eyes full of tears on my eye tracker. Thank you for EVERYTHING Jonah. RIP my dear friend!" he tweeted at the time. 
Am emotional Lomu had visited Van der Westhuizen in the buildup to the 2015 World Cup, paying tribute to the player and the Springboks as part of a documentary he was filming 
There was a mix of joy and tears as they met up. 
"Promise me you'll keep fighting, because I'll keep praying for you," Lomu pleaded to Van der Westhuizen. 
"Take care, my friend," he added as he was about to depart. Lomu hesitated, bent down and kissed the South African, adding "love you" with tears in his eyes. 
Now they are both gone within 15 months of each other, Lomu taken at 40 and Van der Westhuizen at 45. 
South Africans were quick to acknowledge the game and grace of Lomu when he suddenly departed. 
New Zealanders have been just as quick to acknowledge the fighting qualities that set Van der Westhuizen apart, on and off the field. - Stuff
